p: For ASSLB, the use of solid electrolytes requires them to be stable at high potentials vs Li +/Li and compatible with high voltage cathode materials (NMC, NCA) operating up to 4.2/4.3 V [ 96, 119, 120] while remaining compatible with the lithium metal anode. Surprisingly, despite high oxidation limits claimed in most publications (largely above 4.0 V vs. Li +/Li), the electrochemical characterization of these materials in a battery set up is usually performed using LFP cathodes, which have a redox potential of 3.45 V vs. Li +/Li. The fact that the well-known cathode material NMC, which has a potential window of 3.0â€“4.3 V vs. Li +/Li, is not used in these publications to further qualify the stability of their electrolyte leads to questions regarding the validity of the ESW measurement.
